title: Qantas airlines test longest non-stop commercial flight flying 10,200 miles from New York to Sydney
text:
A plane full of 50 passengers will test their mental and physical endurance on an 20 hour, non-stop flight from New York City to Sydney, Australia, in what is being called the ‘final frontier in aviation.’

The test flight, done under Australian commercial airline group Qantas, took off from the JFK airport at 9.27pm on Friday and is expected to land in Sydney at 7.32am on Sunday.

Passenger numbers – mostly made up of Qantas employees – have been restricted to minimize the weight on the Boeing 787-9 plane and in hopes of travelling the 10, 200 miles without re-fueling.

Qantas (pictured) is testing the longest, non-stop flight from New York City to City that will take around 20 hours and won't have to stop for fuel

It’s reported no other airline has successfully completed such an undertaking.

This flight will also be the first time Qantas will be monitoring six volunteers to collect data on a range of variables.

CNBC reports that the volunteers were required to keep journals of their sleeping and eating patterns two weeks before the experimental flight.

Volunteers have also been asked to keep the sleep journals on the flight and two weeks after to create a rounded assessment.

They will reportedly play Whack-a-Mole as they shift through various time zones to gauge their alertness.

Pictured: two maps showing the travel course the Qantas plane will follow on the flight that took of Friday

Pictured: a man who is one of 50 passengers flying on the Qantas test flight for 20 hours

Researchers from the University of Sydney will set up shop in the plane, using the space as a laboratory to monitor things like temperatures, lighting schemes, recipes, stretching exercises and the effects of jet lag.

Sleeping patterns, and melatonin levels, will be one of the most interesting things to monitor as passengers will become impacted by a 15-hour time difference.

University of Sydney professor Stephen Simpson said this flight can help researchers understand the contributions to jet lag.

‘We know from the basic science of circadian rhythms that a bigger time difference between departure and arrival locations, and travelling east rather than west, tends to mean people feel more jetlag,’ he said.

‘But people seem to be wildly different when it comes to the experience of jetlag -- and we need more research on what contributes to jetlag and travel fatigue, so we can try and reduce the impact of long-haul flights.’

Pilots will also be included in the research and have been given special headbands that monitor brain activity.

Pilots (pictured) flying the direct, hours long flight will be wearing special head bands that will monitor their brain activity throughout the hours long journey

They will also provide urine samples to gauge their melatonin, a hormone that regulates that sleep-wake cycle in people.

Cameras will be mounted inside the cockpit to record pilots alertness and they will also be expected to keep sleep journals.

Even with all the hype surrounding the flight, there are still people concerned about the safety of long-haul flights.

Qantas pilots have expressed apprehension about the impact of these lengthy flights have on safety protocols.

The Australian and International Pilots Association said the test flights, ‘will produce a limited set of data that will not adequately replicate real-world flying conditions.’

Shane Loney, the organizations safety director, has suggested a ‘scientific long-term study’ be conducted to measure the impacts on plane crews.

Pictured: a close up look at the headbands pilots will wear during the experimental flight that has some critics worried safety will be compromised for extensive direct flights

He said: ‘Pilots are concerned about being able to get enough quality rest during ultra long-range flights to maintain peak performance and we believe significant caution should be exercised in the initial operations to make sure there are no unintended consequence.’

A Qantas spokesperson said the flight tests are, ‘just one part of the work we are doing to assess how to operate these flights safely.’

But the reality of these long hour flights becoming every day flights is ‘ultimately a business decision,’ Qantas CEO Alan Joyce said.

The economics will need to be in place for it to become regular air travel.

Qantas is encouraging both Boeing and European aerospace company Airbus to develop aircrafts that could complete a task like this with a full set of passengers.

According to Qantas, if all goes well flights are estimated to start in 2022 or 2023.
description: Australian airline Qantas is testing the longest, non-stop flight from New York City to Sydney that will take around 20 hours to complete and researchers will be on board to monitor passengers
